name: ValueSet

element.short: A set of codes drawn from one or more code systems

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: A ValueSet resource instance specifies a set of codes drawn from one or more code systems, intended for use in a particular context. Value sets link between [CodeSystem](codesystem.html) definitions and their use in [coded elements](terminologies.html).

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.comment: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.

element.short: Metadata about the resource

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of its narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies its meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language

element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.comment: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this value set, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this value set is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the value set is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the value set to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the value set (business identifier)
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this value set outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this value set when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the value set
element.comment: There may be different value set instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the value set with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the value set author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.

element.short: How to compare versions
element.comment: If set as a string, this is a FHIRPath expression that has two additional context variables passed in - %version1 and %version2 and will return a negative number if version1 is newer, a positive number if version2 and a 0 if the version ordering can't be successfully be determined.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to compare versions to determine which ValueSet is more current.

element.short: Name for this value set (computer friendly)
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.A name should be provided unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. an anonymous value set in a profile). Most registries will require a name.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A natural language name identifying the value set. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this value set (human friendly)
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the value set.

element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.comment:
Allows filtering of value sets that are appropriate for use versus not.See also the [http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/valueset-workflowStatusDescription](http://hl7.org/fhir/extensions/StructureDefinition-valueset-workflowStatusDescription.html) extension for additional status information related to the editorial process.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this value set. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content. The status of the value set applies to the value set definition (ValueSet.compose) and the associated ValueSet metadata. Expansions do not have a state.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.comment: Allows filtering of value sets that are appropriate for use versus not.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this value set is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level value set.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

element.short: Date last changed
element.comment:
Note that this is not the same as the meta.lastUpdated which is specific to an instance of a value set resource on a server.  Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the value set metadata or content logical definition (.compose) was created or revised.

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the value set. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the value set.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the value set.  May also allow for contact.

element.short: Contact details for the publisher
element.comment:
May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the value set
element.comment: Description SHOULD contain instructions for clinical or administrative use and interpretation and information about misuse. Description SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context. Description SHOULD be populated unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. a value set defined solely in the context of a profile).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A free text natural language description of the value set from a consumer's perspective. The textual description specifies the span of meanings for concepts to be included within the Value Set Expansion, and also may specify the intended use and limitations of the Value Set.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate value set instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for value set (if applicable)

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.comment:
It may be possible for the value set to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

DEPRECATION NOTE: For consistency, implementations are encouraged to migrate to using the new 'jurisdiction' code in the useContext element.  (I.e. useContext.code indicating http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/usage-context-type#jurisdiction and useContext.valueCodeableConcept indicating the jurisdiction.)

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the value set is intended to be used.

element.short: Indicates whether or not any change to the content logical definition may occur
element.comment: Normally immutability is set to 'false', which is the default assumption if it is not populated.  Note that the implication is that if this is set to 'true', there may be only one ValueSet version for this definition. Immutability tends to be set to 'true' in one of two cases: - Where the value set, by the nature of its usage, cannot change.  For example "All specializations of ACT in ActClassCode" - Where there's no safe way to express the "Purpose" such that someone else could safely make changes to the value set definition. Source workflow control must guarantee that the same URI always yields the same definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: If this is set to 'true', then no new versions of the content logical definition can be created.  Note: Other metadata might still change.

element.short: Why this value set is defined
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the value set. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this value set.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Explanation of why this value set is needed and why it has been designed as it has.

element.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions
element.comment: Frequently, the copyright differs between the value set and the codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the value set and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the value set.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the value set and/or its content.

element.short: Copyright holder and year(s)
element.comment: The (c) symbol should NOT be included in this string. It will be added by software when rendering the notation. Full details about licensing, restrictions, warrantees, etc. goes in the more general 'copyright' element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short string (<50 characters), suitable for inclusion in a page footer that identifies the copyright holder, effective period, and optionally whether rights are resctricted. (e.g. 'All rights reserved', 'Some rights reserved').
element.requirements: Defines the content expected to be rendered in all representations of the artifact.

element.short: When the ValueSet was approved by publisher
element.comment:
The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.

element.short: When the ValueSet was last reviewed by the publisher
element.comment:
If specified, this date follows the original approval date.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: When the ValueSet is expected to be used
element.comment:
The effective period for a ValueSet determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a valueset intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The period during which the ValueSet content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting process when new versions of the ValueSet are or are expected to be used instead.

element.short: E.g. Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc
element.comment: DEPRECATION NOTE: For consistency, implementations are encouraged to migrate to using the new 'topic' code in the useContext element.  (I.e. useContext.code indicating http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/usage-context-type#topic and useContext.valueCodeableConcept indicating the topic)

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Descriptions related to the content of the ValueSet. Topics provide a high-level categorization as well as keywords for the ValueSet that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the ValueSet so that it can be found by topical and keyword searches.

element.short: Who authored the ValueSet

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the ValueSet.

element.short: Who edited the ValueSet

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the ValueSet.

element.short: Who reviewed the ValueSet
element.comment: See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization asserted by the publisher to be primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the ValueSet.

element.short: Who endorsed the ValueSet
element.comment: See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization asserted by the publisher to be responsible for officially endorsing the ValueSet for use in some setting.

element.short: Additional documentation, citations, etc
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, dependencies, bibliographic references, and predecessor and successor artifacts.
element.requirements: A ValueSet must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

element.short: Content logical definition of the value set (CLD)

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A set of criteria that define the contents of the value set by including or excluding codes selected from the specified code system(s) that the value set draws from. This is also known as the Content Logical Definition (CLD).

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Fixed date for references with no specified version (transitive)
element.comment: With a defined lockedDate the value set is considered "Locked". Otherwise, the value set may have different expansions as underlying code systems and/or value sets evolve.  The interpretation of lockedDate is often dependent on the context - e.g. a SNOMED CT derived value set with a lockedDate will have a different expansion in USA than in UK.  If a value set specifies a version for include and exclude statements, and also specifies a locked date, the specified versions need to be available that date, or the value set will not be usable.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The Locked Date is  the effective date that is used to determine the version of all referenced Code Systems and Value Set Definitions included in the compose that are not already tied to a specific version.

element.short: Whether inactive codes are in the value set
element.comment:
Note that in the FHIR terminology framework, "deprecated" does not mean inactive, but in some code systems, e.g. LOINC, "deprecated" does mean inactive. Code systems should define what codes are considered to be inactive. If this is not clearly defined (including in the FHIR code system resource), then all codes are assumed to be active.

The Value Set Definition specification defines an ActiveOnly element, which is the reverse of this element e.g. (ValueSet.compose.inactive=FALSE) is the same as (VSD.ActiveOnly=TRUE).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Whether inactive codes - codes that are not approved for current use - are in the value set. If inactive = true, inactive codes are to be included in the expansion, if inactive = false, the inactive codes will not be included in the expansion. If absent, the behavior is determined by the implementation, or by the applicable $expand parameters (but generally, inactive codes would be expected to be included).

element.short: Include one or more codes from a code system or other value set(s)
element.comment: All the conditions in an include must be true. If a system is listed, all the codes from the system are listed. If one or more filters are listed, all of the filters must apply. If one or more value sets are listed, the codes must be in all the value sets. E.g. each include is 'include all the codes that meet all these conditions'.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
A value set include/exclude SHALL have a value set or a system
A value set with concepts or filters SHALL include a system
Cannot have both concept and filter

element.definition: Include one or more codes from a code system or other value set(s).

element.short: The system the codes come from
element.comment: If there are no codes or filters, the entire code system is included. Note that the set of codes that are included may contain abstract codes. See ''Coding.system'' for further documentation about the correct value for the system element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An absolute URI which is the code system from which the selected codes come from.

element.short: Specific version of the code system referred to
element.comment: This is used when selecting the descendants of a concept - they may change between versions. If no version is specified, then the exact contents of the value set might not be known until a context of use binds it to a particular version. The special value '*' means all versions; It is at server discretion regarding expansions and which versions must be supported.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The version of the code system that the codes are selected from, or the special version '*' for all versions.

element.short: A concept defined in the system
element.comment: The list of concepts is considered ordered, though the order might not have any particular significance. Typically, the order of an expansion follows that defined in the compose element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Specifies a concept to be included or excluded.

element.short: Used when the value set is "expanded"
element.comment:
Expansion is performed to produce a collection of codes that are ready to use for data entry or validation. Value set expansions are always considered to be stateless - they are a record of the set of codes in the value set at a point in time under a given set of conditions, and are not subject to ongoing maintenance.

Expansion.parameter is  a simplified list of parameters - a subset of the features of the [Parameters](parameters.html) resource.

Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and managable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).
element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.definition: A code that is a reference to ValueSet.expansion.property.code.

element.short: Value of the property for this concept

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The value of this property.

element.short: SubProperty value for the concept

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A subproperty value for this concept.

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: The value of this subproperty.

element.short: Codes contained under this entry
element.comment: If the expansion uses this element, there is  no implication about the logical relationship between them, and the  structure cannot be used for logical inferencing. The structure  exists to provide navigational assistance for helping human users to  locate codes in the expansion.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Other codes and entries contained under this entry in the hierarchy.

element.short: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be included and why

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be included and why.

element.short: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be excluded and why

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be excluded and why.

description: A ValueSet resource instance specifies a set of codes drawn from one or more code systems, intended for use in a particular context. Value sets link between [[[CodeSystem]]] definitions and their use in [coded elements](terminologies.html).

element.short: A set of codes drawn from one or more code systems

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: A ValueSet resource instance specifies a set of codes drawn from one or more code systems, intended for use in a particular context. Value sets link between [CodeSystem](codesystem.html) definitions and their use in [coded elements](terminologies.html).

element.short: Canonical identifier for this value set, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic

element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this value set is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the value set is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the value set to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

element.short: Additional identifier for the value set (business identifier)
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this value set outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this value set when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the value set
element.comment: There may be different value set instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the value set with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the value set author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.

element.short: How to compare versions
element.comment: If set as a string, this is a FHIRPath expression that has two additional context variables passed in - %version1 and %version2 and will return a negative number if version1 is newer, a positive number if version2 and a 0 if the version ordering can't be successfully be determined.
element.definition: Indicates the mechanism used to compare versions to determine which ValueSet is more current.

element.short: Name for this value set (computer friendly)
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.A name should be provided unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. an anonymous value set in a profile). Most registries will require a name.
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the value set. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this value set (human friendly)
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the value set.

element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.comment:
Allows filtering of value sets that are appropriate for use versus not.See also the [http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/valueset-workflowStatusDescription](http://hl7.org/fhir/extensions/StructureDefinition-valueset-workflowStatusDescription.html) extension for additional status information related to the editorial process.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: The status of this value set. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content. The status of the value set applies to the value set definition (ValueSet.compose) and the associated ValueSet metadata. Expansions do not have a state.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.comment: Allows filtering of value sets that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this value set is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level value set.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

element.short: Date last changed
element.comment:
Note that this is not the same as the meta.lastUpdated which is specific to an instance of a value set resource on a server.  Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the value set metadata or content logical definition (.compose) was created or revised.

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the value set. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the value set.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the value set.  May also allow for contact.

element.short: Contact details for the publisher
element.comment:
May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.

element.short: Natural language description of the value set
element.comment: Description SHOULD contain instructions for clinical or administrative use and interpretation and information about misuse. Description SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context. Description SHOULD be populated unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. a value set defined solely in the context of a profile).
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the value set from a consumer's perspective. The textual description specifies the span of meanings for concepts to be included within the Value Set Expansion, and also may specify the intended use and limitations of the Value Set.

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate value set instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for value set (if applicable)

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.comment:
It may be possible for the value set to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

DEPRECATION NOTE: For consistency, implementations are encouraged to migrate to using the new 'jurisdiction' code in the useContext element.  (I.e. useContext.code indicating http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/usage-context-type#jurisdiction and useContext.valueCodeableConcept indicating the jurisdiction.)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the value set is intended to be used.

element.short: Indicates whether or not any change to the content logical definition may occur
element.comment: Normally immutability is set to 'false', which is the default assumption if it is not populated.  Note that the implication is that if this is set to 'true', there may be only one ValueSet version for this definition. Immutability tends to be set to 'true' in one of two cases: - Where the value set, by the nature of its usage, cannot change.  For example "All specializations of ACT in ActClassCode" - Where there's no safe way to express the "Purpose" such that someone else could safely make changes to the value set definition. Source workflow control must guarantee that the same URI always yields the same definition.
element.definition: If this is set to 'true', then no new versions of the content logical definition can be created.  Note: Other metadata might still change.

element.short: Why this value set is defined
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the value set. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this value set.
element.definition: Explanation of why this value set is needed and why it has been designed as it has.

element.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions
element.comment: Frequently, the copyright differs between the value set and the codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the value set and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the value set.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the value set and/or its content.

element.short: Copyright holder and year(s)
element.comment: The (c) symbol should NOT be included in this string. It will be added by software when rendering the notation. Full details about licensing, restrictions, warrantees, etc. goes in the more general 'copyright' element.
element.definition: A short string (<50 characters), suitable for inclusion in a page footer that identifies the copyright holder, effective period, and optionally whether rights are resctricted. (e.g. 'All rights reserved', 'Some rights reserved').
element.requirements: Defines the content expected to be rendered in all representations of the artifact.

element.short: When the ValueSet was approved by publisher
element.comment:
The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.

element.short: When the ValueSet was last reviewed by the publisher
element.comment:
If specified, this date follows the original approval date.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: When the ValueSet is expected to be used
element.comment:
The effective period for a ValueSet determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a valueset intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.

See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: The period during which the ValueSet content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting process when new versions of the ValueSet are or are expected to be used instead.

element.short: E.g. Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc
element.comment: DEPRECATION NOTE: For consistency, implementations are encouraged to migrate to using the new 'topic' code in the useContext element.  (I.e. useContext.code indicating http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/usage-context-type#topic and useContext.valueCodeableConcept indicating the topic)
element.definition: Descriptions related to the content of the ValueSet. Topics provide a high-level categorization as well as keywords for the ValueSet that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the ValueSet so that it can be found by topical and keyword searches.

element.short: Who authored the ValueSet
element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the ValueSet.

element.short: Who edited the ValueSet
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the ValueSet.

element.short: Who reviewed the ValueSet
element.comment: See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: An individual or organization asserted by the publisher to be primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the ValueSet.

element.short: Who endorsed the ValueSet
element.comment: See guidance around (not) making local changes to elements [here](canonicalresource.html#localization).
element.definition: An individual or organization asserted by the publisher to be responsible for officially endorsing the ValueSet for use in some setting.

element.short: Additional documentation, citations, etc
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, dependencies, bibliographic references, and predecessor and successor artifacts.
element.requirements: A ValueSet must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

element.short: Content logical definition of the value set (CLD)
element.definition: A set of criteria that define the contents of the value set by including or excluding codes selected from the specified code system(s) that the value set draws from. This is also known as the Content Logical Definition (CLD).

element.short: Fixed date for references with no specified version (transitive)
element.comment: With a defined lockedDate the value set is considered "Locked". Otherwise, the value set may have different expansions as underlying code systems and/or value sets evolve.  The interpretation of lockedDate is often dependent on the context - e.g. a SNOMED CT derived value set with a lockedDate will have a different expansion in USA than in UK.  If a value set specifies a version for include and exclude statements, and also specifies a locked date, the specified versions need to be available that date, or the value set will not be usable.
element.definition: The Locked Date is  the effective date that is used to determine the version of all referenced Code Systems and Value Set Definitions included in the compose that are not already tied to a specific version.

element.short: Whether inactive codes are in the value set
element.comment:
Note that in the FHIR terminology framework, "deprecated" does not mean inactive, but in some code systems, e.g. LOINC, "deprecated" does mean inactive. Code systems should define what codes are considered to be inactive. If this is not clearly defined (including in the FHIR code system resource), then all codes are assumed to be active.

The Value Set Definition specification defines an ActiveOnly element, which is the reverse of this element e.g. (ValueSet.compose.inactive=FALSE) is the same as (VSD.ActiveOnly=TRUE).
element.definition: Whether inactive codes - codes that are not approved for current use - are in the value set. If inactive = true, inactive codes are to be included in the expansion, if inactive = false, the inactive codes will not be included in the expansion. If absent, the behavior is determined by the implementation, or by the applicable $expand parameters (but generally, inactive codes would be expected to be included).

element.short: Include one or more codes from a code system or other value set(s)
element.comment: All the conditions in an include must be true. If a system is listed, all the codes from the system are listed. If one or more filters are listed, all of the filters must apply. If one or more value sets are listed, the codes must be in all the value sets. E.g. each include is 'include all the codes that meet all these conditions'.

constraint.human: A value set with concepts or filters SHALL include a system
Cannot have both concept and filter
A value set include/exclude SHALL have a value set or a system

element.definition: Include one or more codes from a code system or other value set(s).

element.short: The system the codes come from
element.comment: If there are no codes or filters, the entire code system is included. Note that the set of codes that are included may contain abstract codes. See ''Coding.system'' for further documentation about the correct value for the system element.
element.definition: An absolute URI which is the code system from which the selected codes come from.

element.short: Specific version of the code system referred to
element.comment: This is used when selecting the descendants of a concept - they may change between versions. If no version is specified, then the exact contents of the value set might not be known until a context of use binds it to a particular version. The special value '*' means all versions; It is at server discretion regarding expansions and which versions must be supported.
element.definition: The version of the code system that the codes are selected from, or the special version '*' for all versions.

element.short: A concept defined in the system
element.comment: The list of concepts is considered ordered, though the order might not have any particular significance. Typically, the order of an expansion follows that defined in the compose element.
element.definition: Specifies a concept to be included or excluded.

element.short: Code or expression from system
element.comment: Expressions are allowed if defined by the underlying code system.
element.definition: Specifies a code for the concept to be included or excluded.

element.short: Text to display for this code for this value set in this valueset
element.comment: The value set resource allows for an alternative display to be specified for when this concept is used in this particular value set. See notes in the value set narrative about the correct use of this element.
element.definition: The text to display to the user for this concept in the context of this valueset. If no display is provided, then applications using the value set use the display specified for the code by the system.

element.short: Additional representations for this concept
element.comment: Concepts have both a ```display``` and an array of ```designation```. The display is equivalent to a special designation with an implied ```designation.use``` of "primary code" and a language equal to the [Resource Language](resource.html#language).

constraint.human: Must have a value for concept.designation.use if concept.designation.additionalUse is present

element.definition: Additional representations for this concept when used in this value set - other languages, aliases, specialized purposes, used for particular purposes, etc.

element.short: Human language of the designation

binding.description: IETF language tag for a human language

element.comment: In the absence of a language, the resource language applies.
element.definition: The language this designation is defined for.

element.short: Types of uses of designations

binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used.

element.comment: If no use is provided, the designation can be assumed to be suitable for general display to a human user.
element.definition: A code that represents types of uses of designations.

element.short: Additional ways how this designation would be used

binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used.

element.comment: This was added rather than increasing the cardinality of .use to 0..* in order to maintain backward compatibility.
element.definition: Additional codes that detail how this designation would be used, if there is more than one use.

element.short: The text value for this designation
element.definition: The text value for this designation.

element.short: Select codes/concepts by their properties (including relationships)
element.comment: Selecting codes by specifying filters based on properties is only possible where the underlying code system defines appropriate properties. Note that in some cases, the underlying code system defines the logical concepts but not the literal codes for the concepts. In such cases, the literal definitions may be provided by a third party.
element.definition: Select concepts by specifying a matching criterion based on the properties (including relationships) defined by the system, or on filters defined by the system. If multiple filters are specified within the include, they SHALL all be true.

element.short: A property/filter defined by the code system
element.definition: A code that identifies a property or a filter defined in the code system.

element.short: = | is-a | descendent-of | is-not-a | regex | in | not-in | generalizes | child-of | descendent-leaf | exists

binding.description: The kind of operation to perform as a part of a property based filter.

element.comment: In case filter.property represents a property of the system, the operation applies to the selected property. In case filter.property represents a filter of the system, the operation SHALL match one of the CodeSystem.filter.operator values.
element.definition: The kind of operation to perform as a part of the filter criteria.

element.short: Code from the system, or regex criteria, or boolean value for exists
element.comment: Use regex matching with care - full regex matching on every SNOMED CT term is prohibitive, for example.
element.definition: The match value may be either a code defined by the system, or a string value, which is a regex match on the literal string of the property value  (if the filter represents a property defined in CodeSystem) or of the system filter value (if the filter represents a filter defined in CodeSystem) when the operation is 'regex', or one of the values (true and false), when the operation is 'exists'.

element.short: Select the contents included in this value set
element.comment: The value set URI is either a logical reference to a defined value set such as a [SNOMED CT reference set](https://terminology.hl7.org/SNOMEDCT.html), or a direct reference to a value set definition using ValueSet.url. The reference might not refer to an actual FHIR ValueSet resource; in this case, whatever is referred to is an implicit definition of a value set that needs to be clear about how versions are resolved.
element.definition: Selects the concepts found in this value set (based on its value set definition). This is an absolute URI that is a reference to ValueSet.url.  If multiple value sets are specified this includes the intersection of the contents of all of the referenced value sets.

element.short: A copyright statement for the specific code system included in the value set
element.definition: A copyright statement for the specific code system asserted by the containing ValueSet.compose.include element's system value (if the associated ValueSet.compose.include.version element is not present); or the code system and version combination (if the associated ValueSet.compose.include.version element is present).

element.short: Explicitly exclude codes from a code system or other value sets
element.comment: Usually this is used to selectively exclude codes that were included by subsumption in the inclusions. Any display names specified for the codes are ignored.
element.definition: Exclude one or more codes from the value set based on code system filters and/or other value sets.

element.short: Property to return if client doesn't override
element.comment: Note that property names can clash, so using a URI is recommended.
element.definition: A property to return in the expansion, if the client doesn't ask for any particular properties. May be either a code from the code system definition (convenient) or a the formal URI that refers to the property. The special value '*' means all properties known to the server.

element.short: Used when the value set is "expanded"
element.comment:
Expansion is performed to produce a collection of codes that are ready to use for data entry or validation. Value set expansions are always considered to be stateless - they are a record of the set of codes in the value set at a point in time under a given set of conditions, and are not subject to ongoing maintenance.

Expansion.parameter is  a simplified list of parameters - a subset of the features of the [Parameters](parameters.html) resource.
element.definition: A value set can also be "expanded", where the value set is turned into a simple collection of enumerated codes. This element holds the expansion, if it has been performed.

element.short: Identifies the value set expansion (business identifier)
element.comment: Typically, this uri is a UUID (e.g. urn:uuid:8230ff20-c97a-4167-a59d-dc2cb9df16dd).
element.definition: An identifier that uniquely identifies this expansion of the valueset, based on a unique combination of the provided parameters, the system default parameters, and the underlying system code system versions etc. Systems may re-use the same identifier as long as those factors remain the same, and the expansion is the same, but are not required to do so. This is a business identifier.

element.short: Opaque urls for paging through expansion results
element.comment: Clients SHOULD use the next link, if present, to page through expansion results in preference to using the offset and count parameters. Due to the optional nature of the next link, its absence does not necessarily indicate that it is the last page of results. Instead, as the offset and count parameters SHALL be populated when paging, clients can reliably use the count/offset parameters to determine whether the whole expansion is returned.
element.definition: As per paging Search results, the next URLs are opaque to the client, have no dictated structure, and only the server understands them.

element.short: Time ValueSet expansion happened
element.comment: This SHOULD be a fully populated instant, but in some circumstances, value sets are expanded by hand, and the expansion is published without that precision.
element.definition: The time at which the expansion was produced by the expanding system.

element.short: Total number of codes in the expansion
element.comment: Paging only applies to flat expansions.
element.definition: The total number of concepts in the expansion. If the number of concept nodes in this resource is less than the stated number, then the server can return more using the offset parameter.

element.short: Offset at which this resource starts
element.comment: Paging only applies to flat expansions. If a filter is applied, the count is the number of concepts that matched the filter, not the number of concepts in an unfiltered view of the expansion.
element.definition: If paging is being used, the offset at which this resource starts.  I.e. this resource is a partial view into the expansion. If paging is not being used, this element SHALL NOT be present.

element.short: Parameter that controlled the expansion process
element.comment: The server decides which parameters to include here, but at a minimum, the list SHOULD include all of the parameters that affect the $expand operation. If the expansion will be persisted all of these parameters SHALL be included. If the codeSystem on the server has a specified version then this version SHALL be provided as a parameter in the expansion (note that not all code systems have a version).
element.definition: A parameter that controlled the expansion process. These parameters may be used by users of expanded value sets to check whether the expansion is suitable for a particular purpose, or to pick the correct expansion.

element.short: Name as assigned by the client or server
element.comment: The names are assigned at the discretion of the server.
element.definition: Name of the input parameter to the $expand operation; may be a server-assigned name for additional default or other server-supplied parameters used to control the expansion process.

element.short: Value of the named parameter
element.definition: The value of the parameter.

element.short: Additional information supplied about each concept
element.definition: A property defines an additional slot through which additional information can be provided about a concept.

element.short: Identifies the property on the concepts, and when referred to in operations
element.definition: A code that is used to identify the property. The code is used in ValueSet.expansion.contains.property.code.

element.short: Formal identifier for the property
element.definition: Reference to the formal meaning of the property. One possible source of meaning is the [Concept Properties](codesystem-concept-properties.html) code system.

element.short: Codes in the value set

constraint.human: SHALL have a code or a display
SHALL have a code if not abstract
SHALL have a system if a code is present

element.definition: The codes that are contained in the value set expansion.

element.short: System value for the code
element.definition: An absolute URI which is the code system in which the code for this item in the expansion is defined.

element.short: If user cannot select this entry
element.comment: This should not be understood to exclude its use for searching (e.g. by subsumption testing). The client should know whether it is appropriate for the user to select an abstract code or not.
element.definition: If true, this entry is included in the expansion for navigational purposes, and the user cannot select the code directly as a proper value.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If this is not populated, systems can assume that the concept it not abstract. This SHALL always be populated for abstract concepts

element.short: If concept is inactive in the code system
element.comment: This should only have a value if the concept is inactive.
element.definition: If the concept is inactive in the code system that defines it. Inactive codes are those that are no longer to be used, but are maintained by the code system for understanding legacy data. It might not be known or specified whether a concept is inactive (and it may depend on the context of use).

element.short: Version in which this code/display is defined
element.comment: The exact value of the version string is specified by the system from which the code is derived.
element.definition: The version of the code system from this code was taken. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.

element.short: Code - if blank, this is not a selectable code
element.definition: The code for this item in the expansion hierarchy. If this code is missing the entry in the hierarchy is a place holder (abstract) and does not represent a valid code in the value set.

element.short: User display for the concept
element.definition: The recommended display for this item in the expansion.

element.short: Additional representations for this item
element.comment: The designations provided must be based on the value set and code system definitions.
element.definition: Additional representations for this item - other languages, aliases, specialized purposes, used for particular purposes, etc. These are relevant when the conditions of the expansion do not fix to a single correct representation.

element.short: Property value for the concept
element.definition: A property value for this concept.

element.short: Reference to ValueSet.expansion.property.code
element.definition: A code that is a reference to ValueSet.expansion.property.code.

element.short: Value of the property for this concept
element.definition: The value of this property.

element.short: SubProperty value for the concept
element.definition: A subproperty value for this concept.

element.short: Reference to ValueSet.expansion.property.code
element.definition: A code that is a reference to ValueSet.expansion.property.code.

element.short: Value of the subproperty for this concept
element.definition: The value of this subproperty.

element.short: Codes contained under this entry
element.comment: If the expansion uses this element, there is  no implication about the logical relationship between them, and the  structure cannot be used for logical inferencing. The structure  exists to provide navigational assistance for helping human users to  locate codes in the expansion.
element.definition: Other codes and entries contained under this entry in the hierarchy.

element.short: Description of the semantic space the Value Set Expansion is intended to cover and should further clarify the text in ValueSet.description
element.definition: Description of the semantic space the Value Set Expansion is intended to cover and should further clarify the text in ValueSet.description.

element.short: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be included and why
element.definition: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be included and why.

element.short: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be excluded and why
element.definition: Criteria describing which concepts or codes should be excluded and why.
